viii ABSTRACT BRITO, Bruna Luiza Ferreira. Reuse of calcined kaolinitic waste in type II cement paste. Disserta√ß√£o (Academic Master in Chemical and Biochemical Process Engineering) ‚Äì Escola de Qu√≠mica, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Rio de Janeiro, 2020.

The reuse of waste as supplementary materials for Portland cement is one of the most promising alternatives for mitigating CO2 emissions from the cement industry. The waste from kaolin processing is basically composed of kaolinite, its calcination forms a product consisting largely of metak aolinite. Thus, this work presents the study of the incorporation of the RC as a precursor of pozzolanic material in partial replacement of cement in pastes. The calcination of the RC was studied, then the characterization of the calcined kaolinitic waste was performed. The levels of RCC used were obtained by the results of the compaction test, they were: 0, 10, 20 and 30% as a replacement for cement in mass. After an increase in particle size was observed after calcination, the grinding of the RCC and its influence on the properties of the pastes replaced by the same contents of unground waste was also studied. The hydration was evaluated from the heat flow curves using an isothermal calorimeter and also through the TG/DTG curves of the pastes, through thes e it was also possible to calculate the hydroxide consumption by the metakaolinite. The hydrated products were analyzed by XRD. The microstructure of the cured pastes was studied by SEM and gas adsorption tests. The mechanical performance was evaluated at 3 and 28 days of curing. From the tests performed it was observed that: the conditions used in calcination allowed to obtain a material with pozzolanic activity, the addition of RCC in the pastes accelerated the hydration reactions of cement, the pozzolani c reaction was significant for the levels studied, which led to changes in the microstructure of the pastes and increased mechanical strength.
Keywords: Portland cement, Waste from kaolin processing, Cement hydration, pozzolanic activity
